stem: Why apply 5S/housekeeping in a welding shop?

choices.text: It reduces waste and improves safety
It means sweeping at the end of the day only

rationales.CHOICE-2: It reduces waste and improves safety

stem: Before starting, consumables should be checked to ensure they:

choices.text: Match the WPS classification and size
Were found on the nearest bench

rationales.CHOICE-1: Match the WPS classification and size

stem: When measuring from drawings, a good practice is to:

choices.text: Use any convenient edge as a baseline
Measure from the designated datum(s) shown

rationales.CHOICE-2: Measure from the designated datum(s) shown

stem: Why should weld sequence and fixturing be planned before welding?

rationales.CHOICE-2: To minimize distortion and rework

stem: 'Do not scale drawing' means you should:

choices.text: Measure distances with a ruler on the print
Rely on stated dimensions and notes, not scaling

rationales.CHOICE-2: Rely on stated dimensions and notes, not scaling

stem: Which practice is correct when using fabrication drawings?

choices.text: Use the latest revision listed in the title block
Let the shop choose per day

rationales.CHOICE-2: Use the latest revision listed in the title block

stem: Before production welding, a good readiness check is to:

choices.text: Verify gas type, pressure, regulators, and spares

rationales.CHOICE-2: Verify gas type, pressure, regulators, and spares

stem: A Job Hazard Analysis (JHA) is used to:

choices.text: Identify hazards and controls for each task step

rationales.CHOICE-2: Identify hazards and controls for each task step

stem: To reduce delays at the bench, parts and hardware should be:

rationales.CHOICE-2: Kitted and staged before setup

stem: To prevent mix‑ups between similar materials, you should:

choices.text: Label clearly and segregate storage locations

rationales.CHOICE-2: Label clearly and segregate storage locations

stem: To improve measurement repeatability between operators, use:

choices.text: Different tools and methods each time

rationales.CHOICE-2: Standardized tools, fixtures, and methods

stem: Why are Mill Test Reports (MTRs) reviewed before fabrication?

choices.text: To verify material grade/heat meets specifications

rationales.CHOICE-2: To verify material grade/heat meets specifications

stem: Which is a sound sequence for organizing a welding job?

choices.text: Start welding, then look for parts
Confirm materials/tools, review WPS & drawings, plan sequence, then set up

rationales.CHOICE-2: Confirm materials/tools, review WPS & drawings, plan sequence, then set up

stem: If schedule pressure conflicts with WPS requirements, you should:

choices.text: Follow the WPS and escalate schedule concerns

rationales.CHOICE-2: Follow the WPS and escalate schedule concerns

stem: Job travelers/routers often include hold points meaning:

rationales.CHOICE-2: Required inspections/approvals before proceeding

stem: At shift handover, a good practice is to:

choices.text: Document status, issues, and next steps for continuity
Leave with work in the machine

rationales.CHOICE-2: Document status, issues, and next steps for continuity

stem: A weld symbol placed below the reference line typically indicates the weld is on the:

rationales.CHOICE-2: Arrow side of the joint

stem: On welding drawings, the basic triangular weld symbol indicates a:

rationales.CHOICE-2: Fillet weld

stem: The symbol '±' on a dimension means:

choices.text: Allowed variation around the nominal size

rationales.CHOICE-2: Allowed variation around the nominal size

stem: Measuring tools used for acceptance should be:

choices.text: Within calibration date and zeroed before use
Shared without cases to save time

rationales.CHOICE-2: Within calibration date and zeroed before use

stem: A short pre‑job briefing (toolbox talk) helps to:

choices.text: Align the team on hazards, sequence, and responsibilities

rationales.CHOICE-2: Align the team on hazards, sequence, and responsibilities

stem: When cutting a marked plate, you should maintain heat/lot traceability by:

choices.text: Transferring heat numbers to each piece and documenting

rationales.CHOICE-2: Transferring heat numbers to each piece and documenting

stem: When drawings mix units (mm/in), the best practice is to:

choices.text: Convert everything mentally on the fly
Follow the units stated for each dimension and avoid mixing

rationales.CHOICE-2: Follow the units stated for each dimension and avoid mixing

stem: What is the primary purpose of a Welding Procedure Specification (WPS)?

choices.text: To define essential variables and parameters for production welds
For inspectors only; welders need not read it

rationales.CHOICE-2: To define essential variables and parameters for production welds

stem: On the floor you have drawing revision D, while the traveler lists revision C. What is the correct action?

choices.text: Proceed with either version—the differences are minor
Stop work, confirm the latest revision, update the traveler/permits, and work only to the current set
Cross out the old revision with a marker

rationales.CHOICE-2: Stop work, confirm the latest revision, update the traveler/permits, and work only to the current set

stem: The heat number on a part does not match the MTR. What should you do?

choices.text: Quarantine the material, tag HOLD, and request a correct MTR/ID from QA/engineering
Erase and re‑stamp a new number
Use it and attach a photo later

rationales.CHOICE-2: Quarantine the material, tag HOLD, and request a correct MTR/ID from QA/engineering

stem: A drawing shows 3/8" but your caliper is in millimeters. Best approach:

choices.text: Estimate by eye and note in mm
Use a tool with the correct units or convert reliably and clearly record units
Hand‑convert the whole drawing to mm

rationales.CHOICE-2: Use a tool with the correct units or convert reliably and clearly record units

stem: An indicator stand is past its calibration date but 'reads fine.' For acceptance measurements you should:

choices.text: Do not use for acceptance; replace with an in‑cal tool/send for calibration

rationales.CHOICE-2: Do not use for acceptance; replace with an in‑cal tool/send for calibration

stem: You are assembling a frame from sections. The best plan to reduce distortion is to:

choices.text: Run one long continuous weld on one side, then the other
Use symmetric tack‑up, skip (staggered) sequence, back‑step, alternate sides, and fixturing
Weld as hot and fast as possible in one direction

rationales.CHOICE-2: Use symmetric tack‑up, skip (staggered) sequence, back‑step, alternate sides, and fixturing

stem: The WPS calls for E7018 Ø3.2 mm, but the crib only has E6013 Ø4.0 mm. Your decision:

choices.text: Use E6013—it’s also a mild‑steel electrode
Do not start; request the correct consumable and/or a WPS change via engineering/QA

rationales.CHOICE-2: Do not start; request the correct consumable and/or a WPS change via engineering/QA

stem: The router has a hold point before the root pass; the inspector is not available. You should:

choices.text: Skip the hold point and weld to avoid delay
Stop at the hold point, call for inspection/authorization, then proceed
Take a photo and move on

rationales.CHOICE-2: Stop at the hold point, call for inspection/authorization, then proceed

stem: After cutting, some parts lost heat/lot markings. Best action:

choices.text: Isolate the parts, restore traceability via records/sampling per procedure, and document
Cut the corner off and discard

rationales.CHOICE-2: Isolate the parts, restore traceability via records/sampling per procedure, and document

stem: Convert 3/8" to millimeters to three decimal places. Choose the most accurate value.
A size is given as 5/16". Round to two decimals in millimeters. What should be recorded?
Convert a tolerance of ±0.010" to millimeters (three decimals).
Which measured value is within 100.00 ± 0.25 mm?
For limit size 1.000" / 0.995", which measurement is acceptable?
A hole Ø0.406" ±0.005" must be documented in mm (round to two decimals). Pick the correct nominal ± tolerance.
Convert 1/4" to millimeters (two decimals).
A fillet weld leg size of 7/16" must be recorded in mm (two decimals). Which is correct?
Convert 1.25" ±0.01" to millimeters (two decimals). Select the correct expression.
For a JHA, choose the correct mapping of 'step — hazards — controls'.

choices.text: Cutting: sparks/slag → safety glasses + face shield, screens, extinguisher; Assembly: pinch points → clamps/fixtures, keep hands clear
Cutting: UV burns → sunscreen; Assembly: chemical poisoning → open windows
Cutting: noise → sunglasses; Assembly: pinch points → remove gloves for feel
Cutting: sparks → remove shield; Assembly: pinch points → work faster

rationales.CHOICE-1: Cutting: sparks/slag → safety glasses + face shield, screens, extinguisher; Assembly: pinch points → clamps/fixtures, keep hands clear

stem: What must be covered in a toolbox talk before 'cutting → fit‑up → welding'?

choices.text: Nothing—figure it out as we go

stem: Fabricating a steel frame 1000×600×6 mm. Which plan minimizes distortion?

choices.text: One continuous long weld on one side, then the opposite
Symmetric tack‑up; skip sequence of short runs; back‑step; alternate sides; use fixturing
From one corner around without stopping

rationales.CHOICE-2: Symmetric tack‑up; skip sequence of short runs; back‑step; alternate sides; use fixturing

stem: Welding a thin‑wall box 500×500×500×3 mm. What helps planarity and geometry?

choices.text: Weld one face continuously, then adjacent faces
Tack at equal spacing; short runs alternating faces; allow cooling; use braces/fixtures
Max heat input to finish faster
Close all seams fully without pauses

rationales.CHOICE-2: Tack at equal spacing; short runs alternating faces; allow cooling; use braces/fixtures

stem: On a drawing: “3/8‑16 UNC, depth 25 mm.” What does “25 mm” specify?

rationales.CHOICE-2: Threaded depth of 25 mm

stem: A positional tolerance callout for a hole reads: “⌀0.50 | A | B |”. What does this mean?

choices.text: The surface must be parallel to datums A and B
The hole axis must lie within a cylindrical zone of diameter 0.50 relative to datums A and B
The hole size may be scaled from the print
It’s a flatness symbol unrelated to axes

rationales.CHOICE-2: The hole axis must lie within a cylindrical zone of diameter 0.50 relative to datums A and B

stem: The callout “∥ 0.20 | A” for a surface indicates:

choices.text: The surface must lie between two parallel planes 0.20 apart, parallel to datum A

rationales.CHOICE-2: The surface must lie between two parallel planes 0.20 apart, parallel to datum A

stem: At a hold point an out‑of‑tolerance fillet size is found: 7.2 mm vs requirement 8.0 ± 0.5 mm. What is the best course of action?

choices.text: Build up to 8 mm and skip paperwork to save time

Stop work, segregate the part, raise an NCR; choose disposition—rework to drawing size, or use‑as‑is ONLY with engineering approval, or scrap; record the decision on the router/traveler before continuing
Send it forward, marking the spot with a marker
Widen the tolerance on the shop floor so it passes

rationales.CHOICE-2: Stop work, segregate the part, raise an NCR; choose disposition—rework to drawing size, or use‑as‑is ONLY with engineering approval, or scrap; record the decision on the router/traveler before continuing
